channel.title: Vps
channel.description: I have a vps, i was wondering if my provider can check the items i have in it, its a windows server 2008.

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:29, topic:548381”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=667287.msg4463059#msg4463059 date=1418591353]

You can still use a random seed to over come that.

Wat.

It’s a similar thing that barclays use for online banking. You have this thingy that generates a random number that allows you to login. Once it’s been used once it can’t be used again.
Same thing can be applied for an app.

They only need you to use it once… they are in possession of the storage, ram, hypervisor, cpu…

Besides which, the Barclays style key wouldn’t be useful here, since that’s just used for authentication, it doesn’t actaully decrypt anything.
[/quote]
Maybe not, still can be used to password protect his files.[/quote]

But then he wouldn’t need the VPS for anything other than hosting files - which he can do almost everywhere.

But as he says here V he’s not hosting files but running a server. He isn’t hiding that without significant work, which can be “revealed” with an equal amount of significant work.

[quote=“Strucker, post:7, topic:548381”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=667287.msg4462525#msg4462525 date=1418254040]
Just encrypt your data if you don’t want them seeing your files. Password protect them etc.

What type of shitty VPS company are you going to anyway? They shouldn’t really be snooping through your files.
[/quote]I’m just being curious, but if i encrypt it i cant be running for example a server, can i?[/quote]

Read full topic

It’s a similar thing that barclays use for online banking. You have this thingy that generates a random number that allows you to login. Once it’s been used once it can’t be used again.
Same thing can be applied for an app.
[/quote]

They only need you to use it once… they are in possession of the storage, ram, hypervisor, cpu…

Besides which, the Barclays style key wouldn’t be useful here, since that’s just used for authentication, it doesn’t actaully decrypt anything.[/quote]

Wat.
[/quote]
It’s a similar thing that barclays use for online banking. You have this thingy that generates a random number that allows you to login. Once it’s been used once it can’t be used again.
Same thing can be applied for an app.[/quote]

They only need you to use it once… they are in possession of the storage, ram, hypervisor, cpu…

Besides which, the Barclays style key wouldn’t be useful here, since that’s just used for authentication, it doesn’t actaully decrypt anything.

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:26, topic:548381”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=667287.msg4463018#msg4463018 date=1418579238]

a seed is the initial state of a PRNG. What you’re referring to is random key authentication.

I was thinking of a PRNG because I think that’s exactly what barclays use anyway, the keys are generated are not really random.
[/quote]wow arithmetic random is not really random
you are pretty insightful, thanks for your contributions to this forum

No, arithmetic random wasn’t what I’m thinking about.[/quote]i know what you mean but they are generated and as such must appear to be random, ie pseudo random ie same idea

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Which also wouldn’t work because as Mopman points out they’ll be able to obtain the key - how easy that is depends on the implementation. It may be non-trivial to bypass but they’ll have everything they need to do so.

It’s a fairly significant exercise to even attempt to hide what you’re doing on a VPS - they have just as much access as you do plus more, but it’s not something you need to worry about doing if all you’re doing is running a RSPS that’s not going to get enough traffic to cause them any hassle.

Read full topic

Just encrypt your data if you don’t want them seeing your files. Password protect them etc.
